review: Atmospheric and strange. Great sound design. Probably not for everyone, but if you're a fan of weird fiction and games that are artistic and exploration based it's worth a play. I'd consider it roughly the same genre as Empathy Path of Whispers, but with visuals that are more bleak and haunting rather than epic and fantastical. The story builds gradually and with a sense of dread. "Bleak", "haunting", and "dread" probably make it sound like a downer to play, but the atmosphere is strangely calming, which makes the simple gameplay almost meditative. The ending is baffling, so if you need a conclusive ending it may not be the game for you.

review:
Ok, small game and made by what I can see either a small team or one guy. Has a great idea for a horror concept, having a recorder to help decipher ghost messages and see whether or not it's a threat or a story unraveling. I love it a lot, going through everything, playing with audio is so interesting. Going in reverse, slowing it, making it play faster, just a concept I haven't seen yet. 

One thing to note about it is that the game is primarily puzzles. Little action that means hardly anything, but it's meaningful nonetheless. And with that, the first puzzle is kinda bad to lock the player to the rest of the game, just felt less clear than it should've been. 

Beyond that, I suggest you keep this game at max volume. Do not change it or adjust it, leave it how it is. Because there was a moment while in an ashy, red forest, I heard what sounded like distant growling in one direction through the recording mic. Thinking it was an easter egg, I followed it and followed it. It kept going on for what felt like 20 minutes until nothing. Not a sound. Pure silence. Not a single ripple, drop, crunch or anything, just the pop from the mic. It sent chills down my spine and I don't think that was intentional.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026218489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 202, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1686427568}
review:
First thing you need to know about Sylvio: it is a bit rough around the edges. But, if you can look beyond this, there's a decent and interesting atmospheric horror game behind it. Having just finished my play-through of this on Youtube, I've enclosed a link below for anyone who wants to see a sample of gameplay before deciding to buy.

I'll try to summarise the plot here without being too spoiler-y. Sylvio puts you in the shoes of Juliette Waters, a ghost recorder who one night enters the abandoned Saginaw Park and begins uncovering the grisly secrets buried there (both literally and figuratively) using her audio recording equipment. As the game unfolds, you learn of the disaster that struck the park in bygone years and the sinister things that happened to it afterward. The story is a little cryptic, told through snippets of information gleaned from listening to ghosts or from tape reels left in the environment - so the plot is, to an extent, left to the player to figure out. I thought it worked, personally - it's that old horror adage of giving your audience a few hints, then leaving other aspects to their imagination.

The graphics may be somewhat dated, but personally I felt that they still work well for the atmosphere that the game is seeking to create. And speaking of atmosphere, there's plenty of it - no cheap jump-scares or fast-paced monster chases (though there are definitely threats you need to watch out), just a dark and unsettling vibe as you traverse the foggy landscape and rusty, decaying landmarks of Saginaw Park.

Where this game excels is in its sound design - which is arguably the key ingredient, since Sylvio is all about using your audio equipment to detect, listen to and record ghosts. The audio game mechanics are what makes Sylvio stand out from other horror games. As you come across ghosts and hold occasional seances, your equipment will record what these ghosts say - but their voices are scrambled and distorted, and so it's up to you to un-scramble them using your equipment. Reverse the audio, speed it up, slow it down, or a combination of these, and you'll uncover what it is the spirits are trying to communicate. This does lead to some good, spine-tingling moments where you un-scramble what sounds like demonic gibberish only to discover that you're hearing a ghost dropping some macabre hints about how it died.

As mentioned above, whilst the game is mostly a slow-building form of horror spent exploring Saginaw Park's remains, there are threats you need to watch out for. Not all the ghosts are docile; some, which take the form of shapeless black clouds or gigantic humanoid forms, are dangerous if you get too close. Not that there's much of a penalty if they get you - fortunately, Sylvio autosaves everytime you do something of any significance (such as recording a ghost or finding a collectible), so you don't need to worry about losing huge amounts of progress if you get unlucky and a hostile ghost sneaks up on you.

Plus, you do have a means to defend yourself. Early in the game, Juliette finds an improvised gun that uses old pesticide spray cans as propellant and which can be used to fire a variety of projectile types found in the environment - baseballs, rusty nails, stones, potatoes and more. Some of these (such as the nails) can be used to drive back hostile ghosts. Others (such as potatoes or baseballs) don't do much damage to ghosts but can be used to trigger things in your environment - such as hitting certain switches or knocking items off ledges that are out of reach. The gun mechanic is interesting, though it is one of the elements of Sylvio that would have benefited from a bit more polish - I did find it a bit janky at times, though fortunately this jankiness wasn't unbearable.

So, in short, Sylvio is a bit rough around the edges but it is an interesting take on horror. Would definitely recommend giving it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970831764', 'num_games_owned': 1022, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1656450873}
review:
Sylvio is pretty rough around the edges. It’s a ghost hunting game where you travel around abandoned areas in the outskirts of some forsaken woods. You’re capturing the dead through audio -- at least what’s left of them and their stories. 

It’s actually a great way to tell a story a couple of words at a time, carefully letting you piece together a larger puzzle. It’s also where the game builds a lot of its atmosphere, constantly surrounding and overpowering you with noise, through a sound design that really jostles your attention and imagination

There’s this great bit where you get to analyze your sound library after a discovery. At first glance it’s just filled with static and babel. But by running it backwards, or in slow motion, you find hidden messages that reveal more pieces to the puzzle. 

It’s a super fun, detective-like part of Sylvio that is sadly overshadowed by what can only be described as [i]the rest of the game[/i]. It’s the less flattering part. The less fun one. The one where you travel around inexplicable, awkward terrain -- sometimes by car -- in order to reach points of interest. Interspersed with puzzle solving and combat where you shoot apparitions with a potato cannon. 

It’s a mess, to be honest. Which is a shame, seeing as the game is so close to being a horror game about something more substantial; a lot more specific and interesting. But instead of being a game about deduction and listening, it turns into a more abstract one where you’re once again just chasing down waypoints ad nauseum.

Love the theme, not so much the execution. Thumbs down for me.
developer_response: Hi! Happy you found the audio analyzing parts of Sylvio interesting, sorry to hear that you didn't find the other parts as fun. Just wanted to say that I intended the game to be a calm, atmospheric kind of experience, and fully understand that the exploring and driving can be a bit on the slow side for some players. Thanks for taking the time to write a review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198183077118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1509827070}
review:
I would say that Sylvio 1 is a puzzle game with a spooky theme: it starts out with a few simple environment puzzles, like clearing a blocked path, but quite soon, more complex puzzles of increasing difficulty are introduced. Sound is a major part and analysing what you hear around you is introduced from the start, using your microphone to communicate with what might still be lingering, or gain access to hidden items. Using an old reel to reel player/recorder instead of a modern, digital variant, adds to the spooky vibe as the reels spin up and down.

There are no jump scares and the game is more creepy than scary. Communicating with the ghosts can be pretty intense, since you have to listen closely to what they say or else you might miss important clues, and sometimes disturbing or instilling a feeling of unease. The ghosts are more often suggested than shown, but there are times when you have to fight some of them—using one of the best (and possibly also the quirkiest) weapons I’ve seen so far in a game.

The story has to be pieced together as you delve deeper, and was pretty interesting with a few twists, albeit a bit “all over the place”. I thought everything connected without any obvious plot-holes, although I haven’t fully pieced everything together yet. Don’t play the game for the story alone, but for everything combined: the developer has squeezed in a lot of great stuff to enjoy and explore.

I quite liked how the main protagonist was delivering her lines and thought it made a lot of sense for her not to be loud or pushy. For the other voice actors, I could hear a bit of an accent, which might be immersion breaking if one is extra sensitive to that sort of thing.

Sound is mainly provided by the environment, but the game also has a great soundtrack mostly heard when you’re driving between levels, so if you want to take a break and just relax for a while, without leaving the game, you can drive around while listening to the music and, like I did, crashing into trees a lot.

Can I recommend Sylvio 1? Yes, definitely, I loved every second of it and I think you would too if you’re into puzzle solving, first person exploration, or sound analysis. On the other hand, if you are obsessed with superrealistic graphics, then you might want to play something else: the game has its own unique style, which I appreciated, but others might not. The crudeness in style is, in my opinion, well compensated by gameplay, atmosphere, soundtrack etc...

review:
[h1]«Откуда ты знаешь, что ты не пациент?»[/h1]
[b](с). из игры Outlast[/b]


[b][u]Sylvio[/u][/b] – это приключенческий инди неинфарктный хоррор от 1-го лица, ещё один «всход теплицы» [b]Greenlight[/b], который, к моему глубокому удивлению, пустил к себе в свой уютный домик и, наблюдая за моей очарованностью внутренним убранством, закрыл еле слышно за мною дверь на несколько замков… Но я даже и не думал оборачиваться.


[h1][b]==========[/b][/h1]
[quote][b]Введение:[/b][/quote]
Нас встречает яркий свет уличного фонаря посреди деревьев, глубокая космическая музыка и приятный женский голос: [i]«Меня зовут Джулия Вотерс. Я занимаюсь записью звука в сфере EVP (electronic voice phenomena; звуки, обнаруживаемые на электронных записях и интерпретируемые как голоса духов). Или как говорят мои друзья, я – охотник за голосами призраков. Но я вижу это скорее, как общение в обе стороны, ведь мне интересно узнать почему духи решают задержаться между мирами, а может они и вовсе лишены выбора. Возможно что-то удерживает их здесь, возможно я смогу им помочь сделать шаг к свету… Я не знаю, но я могу слышать их, они говорят, и поэтому я записываю их голоса. Я живу в двух часах езды от известного семейного парка, который был закрыт уже долгое время, но я слышала, туда есть другой проход по старому деревянному мосту. Я только купила старое записывающее оборудование и решила, что это будет отличное место, чтобы его протестировать.»[/i]
Вы – Джулия Вотерс, охотник за голосами призраков. Удачи и да поможет вам Бог.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2799830930
[h1][b]==========[/b][/h1]


[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]

[quote][b]Атмосфера:[/b][/quote]
Вот положа руку на сердце, у меня сложилось ощущение будто я тону, но я умиротворён, заворожён, и будто бы сам начинаю грести руками, погружаясь всё глубже в эту мягкую, сладкую бесконечность. Я не знаю, как бы точнее описать эти ощущения, это надо пропустить через себя самому, ибо множество аспектов, которые далее будут перечислены, сыграли в одно гармоничное произведение.

[quote][b]Звук/Музыка:[/b][/quote]
Музыка – ощущение космоса, бесконечности, с налётом призрачности. Музыка для души, умиротворения, спокойствия, несмотря на то, что у нас  хоррор, игра не обезображена музыкальной истерией по ушам и сердцу. 
[b][u]Музыка, как тонкая материя между наших миром и миром духов.[/u][/b]
Звук работает со всех сторон: голос главной героини, шепчущей [b]ASMR[/b]-ом, как бы боясь потревожить этот призрачный мир вокруг себя; звуки окружения; леденящие душу завывания на фоне. Хоррор здесь работает скорее образами, нежели примитивизмом.
[b][u]Звук, как инструмент проникновения в призрачную материю.[/u][/b]

[quote][b]Сюжет:[/b][/quote]
Заинтриговал изначально. Поохотиться на призраков без помощи протонных бластеров, вызвало неподдельный интерес, я старался выхватывать всю доступную информацию по мере прохождения, понять, что вообще происходит? 
И кстати говоря, концовка оставила после себя достаточно много вопросов, да и не только она… Однако, я не был взбешён этим фактом, я был сосредоточен на попытке понимания, и это – прекрасное ощущение.

[quote][b]Геймплей:[/b][/quote]
У нас есть:[list]
[*]Микрофон со встроенным осциллографом;
[*]Магнитафон;
[*]Блокнот с ручкой;
[*]Пневмо-ружьё (с виду самопальное)
[*]Машина (!).[/list]
У нас есть 3 вида работы с аудио:[list]
[*]Отдельные слова и фразы в шуме статики;
[*]Длинные предложения с разного рода изменением голоса (ревёрс, замедление, ускорение). Для расшифровки которых, мы работаем непосредственно с записью при помощи магнитафона;
[*]Найденные аудиозаписи.
Если у нас [b][u]есть ружьё[/u][/b], значит из него по кому-то [b][u]надо лупить[/u][/b], однако не одним уроном едины, оно пригодится и для решения задачек. У нас есть два типа патронов: острые и тупые (первые для урона, вторые для решения головоломок). Но помните, ваше главное оружие – это микрофон и магнитафон.
[b][u]Обезвреживание духов, поиск отзвуков призраков, новой информации – это ключи[/u][/b] к прохождению, ибо на локации по ходу прогресса появляются новые метки. Кстати говоря, даже если визуально вы нащупаете какой-то интересный предмет, вы его не подберёте раньше времени, пока на нём метка не появится.
[b][u]Поездка на машине, спасает потраченное время[/u][/b] и ноги главной героини.
[b][u]Ворон[/u][/b] – птица мудрая, ворон [b][u]помогает[/u][/b]. Не бойтесь его, следуйте за ним, он подскажет.

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]

[b][u]Визуал крайне небогат[/u][/b], хоть и немного приятен, однако не отпугивает от слова «совсем». Мне вообще было всё равно, насколько порой несуразно всё выглядит и местами пустынно.
[b][u]Проблема неосновных локаций[/u][/b]. Если на машине по большой центральной локации дают покататься, то многие неосновные локации, имея слишком широкий излишний масштаб, не имеют возможности вместить 4-х колсёного друга.
[b][u]Невозможность бега[/u][/b]. Да, по сути бегать то не от кого, но поймите правильно, неосновные локации, отмеченные выше, местами могут утомить, особенно если вы любитель полазить, где не просят.
[b][u]Отсутствие озвучки, отсутствие субтитров на аудиозаписях, в интро[/u][/b]. Опять же, может стать проблемой для многих людей. Английского много (не как в условном [b]Neverwinter Nights[/b], если играть на английском), слушать много. Благо ещё, когда работаешь с пойманными голосами, слова выписываются в блокнот, а во время путешествия, пока главная героиня озвучивает свои мысли, это выводится на экран. Но тем не менее, проект средней сложности в плане усвоения материала.




[quote][i]«Боялся, очень долго откладывал, думал, что там совсем нет субтитров, как я буду это проходить в полном непонимании, однако справился, спасибо, что всё-таки есть письменные вариации текста. Этот проект времён Greenlight - очень хороший пример того, как создать мощный поток, водоворот, способный утянуть за собой без права возврата, на скопленные средства из свиньи-копилки за время учёбы в школе. Terror Meter 1/10
Narrative Intrigue 4/10
Visuals 2/10
Difficulty 3/10
Length <4hrs

Sylvio is a Puzzle Exploration Shooter game, with a creepy atmosphere which takes place over large maps. The player is exploring the remnants of an old theme park, and what brought the place to ruin. With the use of Audio Recording Equipment, listen to the ghosts and discover what actually happened.

On each map the player explores, they will be looking for ghostly apparitions which can either take the form of a general location, white orbs or black clouds. Locations are simply points the player will be guided towards to record a ghostly apparition. The white orbs are passive and the player will simply need to find the correct spot around them in order to record the ghost. While the black clouds can injure the player should they get close. In order to get rid of the black clouds the player needs to use the potato gun with a sharp object to injure them, the amount of shots needed to kill a black cloud increases through the game. Once the player destroys the cloud they are able to then record the ghost.

If the player destroys all of the black clouds in an area then a giant ghost will spawn, like with the black clouds the player will need to load their potato gun with sharp objects and shoot each enough times to deal with them, the amount of shots escalates per level the player is on. Should you get too close to the giant ghost the player will be injured and collapse, the ghosts will attack the player with a black fog from a distance which will also cause damage. The black cloud can be hard to see, and may kill the player before they realise what is happening. Once the giant ghost is dealt with the player will once more be able to record audio.

Once the player has recorded a ghost they will need to listen to what the ghost says by rewinding and listening to the tape. The player may need to go back and forwards through each recording at different speeds before they can find the ghost's message. I found the puzzles of working out what the ghost was saying to be one of the more enjoyable parts of the game, as each time you listened to the ghost stories you found out more of what actually happened in the park.

It is not easy to find the ghost apparitions, the player will need to explore old structures and attractions. In order to get through them the player will need to complete puzzles to open up the maps. This will be done with the use of the Potato gun and hard objects which can be used to knock over objects. The puzzles are not difficult, but can be hard to find some of the locations with there only being one approach.

The player will be traversing large maps in the game in order to find the ghosts' apparitions, the player will need to drive to get from point to point as locations can be minutes away from each other. Driving in Sylvio is very basic, though does suffer with some ragdoll moments which can send the car spinning should the player crash. 

Sylvio’s story is interesting with lots of events leading up to the collapse of the park, and multiple stories coalescing from different perspectives. The story is told in such a disjointed way that it makes it really intriguing trying to learn more of what happened. Now saying that, by the time I was near the end of the game, I did get confused on what was happening anymore, to the point I would need to go through the game again to work out what goes on at the end.

Sylvio is not difficult, the problem comes that it is really easy to get confused on puzzles, parts can easily be missed, while others parts you may not realise you can interact with. This seems to be at worst in the Carnival, in which multiple attractions need to be interacted with in different ways to progress the game. At the same time puzzles that involve dropping platforms can be invisible in the red fog unless you are at the correct angle. It can come to such a problem that if you just do not notice a bullseye you can be wandering in circles for ages trying to find a way in.

When it comes to visuals, Sylvio is not a nice game to look at, maps can be bare, or so coated in mist that most locations are hard to make out. The theme park visuals of the early game are quickly lost to bare maps, in which the player will spend a lot of the game just driving from place to place. Buildings feel compact and tight, and having to explore them is both annoying and compact.

Do not come into Sylvio expecting a horror game, at times it can be creepy with the story behind the events and seeking ghosts. There are no scares, or real threats apart from dealing with the giant ghostly forms, shooting dark clouds at the player. 

Still I really enjoyed Sylvio, and I am not really sure why. The puzzles were fun, and offered a fair challenge to work out where to go, some of the more enjoyable ones were tactically shooting potatoes to open doors. The story was interesting, though I did get a bit confused the further I went in. I guess I truly enjoyed the game because it is such a unique experience that I find it hard to compare it to other games.

If you want to see what the gameplay is like then check the video below, I would advise you just about twenty minutes in, to see more of the exploration parts:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f3vSDmzsN0M

You can find other games I recommend in my curator feed:

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41770172/

review: I didn't know what to expect going into this except for that it had spooky ghosts. I was not prepared for the surreal joys of driving from haunted ruin to haunted ruin, through the red mists and buried wreckage, listening to spooky minimalist electronica on my way to conduct ghost interviews. Very strange experience, riding the line between goofy – contrived physics puzzles and blasting ghosts with a potato gun – and profound – uncovering the trail of betrayals and monstrosities that lead to, seemingly, the earth itself rising up to destroy the old amusement park. Somehow, all these strange pieces just feel right together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010443359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 461, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1640947741}
review:
The idea of the game is cool.
You hunt ghosts, listen to spirits, decode hidden messages and resolve mini puzzles to go to the next stage.
Sylvio is just really badly designed and boring, I can't recommend it.

First, you can't run, in a world that big it's a massive mistake.
You are just wasting my time by making me walk that much and it's incredibly tedious.

Second, the gun is tr*sh.
You have 2 bullets, one to knock objects over and another that kill spirits.
Your gun is powered by gas cans.
You don't have magazines on that gun so the last bullet you put in the gun is the one you will shoot first.
Do I have to explain what's the problem ? 
I can't just have 1 magazine for each kinds of ammo, no, I have to shoot the useless bullets and waste gas if the next bullet I shoot is the wrong one.
There is bullets and gas cans in the environment but in a game where you can't run it's really lame to go back non stop for resources.

Thirdly, it's repetitive, it never try to surprise or diversify the experience to the point I wasn't even feeling like I was playing a horror game.
The creep factor isn't there, I just felt like I was listening to records and not interacting directly with spirits, in my opinion this game is a big missed oppurtinity.
Stage after stage you are alway doing the same sh*t non stop, it's just the puzzles that change a little bit but that's it.
The spirits you are destroying are just clouds and there never is more than 1 coming to attack you, that's laughable.

At last the story is fragmented so much I didn't understand anything, at the end I was just like ''Ok, that's it ?''.
I understood what everyone said very well but I really didn't get the full picture at all honestly, maybe it was just because I was bored to death or I'm stupid, I don't know.

In short, the execution ruin the game completely and the horror in that game just isn't there so it's just really boring and tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993118789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1636752838}
review:
[i] I’ve pressed play to hear what the EVP caught in the wind. Among the static, a broken women’s voice can be heard. She speaks in slow and melancholic tone “I didn’t want to… Daddy… They put me to sleep… I’m not alo…” Her voice turns to short scream. I’ve stopped the recording and played it backwards, at half the playback speed. At first there was nothing except distortion but a faint sound can be heard. It’s a horrid imitation of human speech, with no discernable accent or phonetic pattern. Its words now etched into my mind: SHE IS HERE WITH ME.” [/i]

In the late seventies, something terrible has happened in the Saginaw Park. Since then, no living creature, except for the crows, can live there. You play as Juliette Waters, a professional Ghost Whisperer, as she travels into the park to put her skills to the ultimate test.

Sylvio is a first-person survival horror game inspired by Silent Hill games and Twin Peaks in the best possible way. Its unique story premise, creepy atmosphere, and bone-chilling ghost recording gameplay left me in awe and hooked till the end. Considering it’s made by one person, this amazing horror indie game is very rough in its execution.

You‘ll spend 70% of the time investigating and solving puzzles, and 30% shooting and defending yourself. There are 13 chapters/levels in the game and you’ll need between 8-12 hours to complete the game. You start each level by using the Electronic Voice Phenomenon recorder to capture the messages from ghost residues or trapped apparitions.  Since ghosts exist in a realm where time flows differently, you’ll manipulate the playback speed and direction to uncover what they have to say.

Some of these ghosts will part with their secrets peacefully, while you’ll have to “reason” with others before communicating by using your compressor shotgun. As much as the investigation and sound manipulation segment of the game excels, the combat is quite floaty and imprecise, barely getting a passing grade.

The biggest problem with this game is sheer obscurity on what to do next. Puzzles in the first few levels are straightforward and logical. As I reached the second part of the game, I was often stumped on how to proceed, as puzzles can reach the infamous “moon logic” levels of difficulty. When you uncover how to proceed, you’ll scratch your head thinking how that puzzle made any sense.

Controls are also obscure, with too many keyboard input requirements for something simple. There is a guide in the main menu that I recommend you to read first. Even after this, I didn’t realize how to change and use objects in my inventory until near the end of the game. Your gun, for example, uses two types of ammo: solid, blunt objects to solve puzzles, and sharp and deadly ones to fight the ghosts. 

On top of this, you’ll notice a small compressor meter on the gun that loses its power every time you shoot. You’ll have to pick up compressed pesticide canisters to refill your weapon’s range and power. And all of this could’ve been simplified or better explained in the game, but it’s not.

Regardless, the outstanding sound and music immersed me completely and sealed the deal for me. Talking to ghosts got me unnerved every time. Juliette sounds like a curious and fearless kid, and yet very fragile and afraid adult at the same time. The voice cast in general is superb. 

The graphics are okay, but the art direction is amazing. Decrepit and mist-filled park locations felt eerie, packed with tension, unwelcoming and alien. Lastly, the unfolding story never disrespected my intelligence and chewed plot points for me. You’ll uncover some answers, but you’ll have to use your brain to get the full picture.

Among throngs of cheap jumpscare games out there, Sylvio has masterfully done the rising dread and uncertainty. If you can go past through rough design and no hand holding, this game will leave a lasting mark, just like a well told short horror story does.

[i] The young man’s voice has changed to a rhythmic thumping sound as if it’s trying to tear the fabric of the universe apart, “…the blood of the mist inside my skin.” Only the screams of others could be heard in the background. [/i]

review: I was sufficiently enjoying this game, exploring around, trying to find every achievement, until I got to a part of the game where the only way to progress is to [spoiler] stun, capture, and burn alive 4 crows [/spoiler]. So far, the game had no violence in it, which is one of the things that drew me in: I try to avoid violent video games, but I love ghost stories, and what I had read about this made it sound like the perfect fit. The story was dark alright, but pretty hard to grasp, and I assumed either it would make more sense as you went along, or I'd stop near the end and try to piece everything together. The main character enters the park supposedly to try and help lost souls that may have been trapped there. She can leave whenever she wants, she knows the way out, has a working car, and everything. And yet she still doesn't seem to show the least bit of apprehension when she decides that, [spoiler] in order to get a lantern working, she should kill 4 innocent birds [/spoiler]. It didn't make sense story-wise, the idea of it doesn't make sense in real life at all either, and it definitely crossed a line for me, by so readily including animal cruelty as a puzzle. Everything else so far was fine, but just that; it wasn't impressive or anything, had too much backtracking, and blind exploration on repetitive environments. I definitely don't recommend it.
developer_response: SPOILERS AHEAD! Hi! Sorry about the late reply. Just wanted to say that you're not burning the crows alive. You're making them unconscious, and then putting them into a machine where they are kept in a state of limbo between life and death. Anyone would be able to open the cages, and they would be fine. The bird bones on the attic are from former experiments conducted by the antagonist of the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969658174', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1621876582}
review:
[h1]Sylvio Santos vem aí, lá lá lá lá lá lá [/h1]

[b]|***| Análise completa de quem jogou até o fim |***|[/b]

Jogado com [b]Steam Controller[/b]

+ Trilha sonora anos 80 escassa, mas interessante
+ Boa dublagem
- Gráficos ultrapassados
- Jogabilidade truncada
- Vai-e-vem cansativo para resolução de puzzles
- Ninguém vai desligar a lanterna


=======|||||||=======
[b]ANÁLISE[/b]

Enquanto jogava Sylvio e progredia na história comecei a pensar na análise no Steam, afinal já tem tempo que esse burro velho não escreve nada por essas bandas e meus fiéis 38 seguidores já devem se perguntar onde diabos estão aquelas análises que ninguém se importa, inclusive eles. Pois bem, quanto mais eu me aproximava do final, mais o dilema de Commodus me assolava: polegar para o alto ou polegar para baixo?

Polegar para baixo. Sylvio é um jogo fraco e isso precisa ser dito.

Videogames ainda são feitos para serem jogados (sei lá, vai que alguém resolve inventar jogos para comer ou cheirar) e o “jogar” de Sylvio não foi uma experiência agradável, que pode ser resumido em dois adjetivos: feio e chato.

Sim, Sylvio é um jogo muito feio. É um jogo de baixo orçamento e de 6 anos atrás? Sim e sim, mas graficamente falando ele está no mínimo uns 10 anos atrasado. A sensação é de jogar algo de PS2/Xbox. 

E quando digo jogar algo antigo não me refiro só a parte gráfica, a jogabilidade e as mecânicas implementadas em Sylvio são de 15 anos atrás. Controles duros, movimentação arrastada, física em slow motion e nas fases em que guiamos um “belíssimo” Lada Laika 69 chega a dar pena de tão ruim que é controlar aquela lada velha. Pelo menos o dev criou uma mecânica de spawn do carro pressionando Q. Vou te contar, o que aquele carro trava no cenário é uma piada, mesmo assim o fato de precisar desse spawn constante é tenebroso.

Sylvio é chato em muitas partes. Em especial na área aberta do parque, uma área bem grande onde precisamos usar o Lada velha para ir de um lado para o outro e que basicamente serve de hub para as demais fases. No zoológico também rola um vai-e-vem que eu vou te contar, por sorte já estamos perto do final.

Outra coisa que não entendi em Sylvio foi a lanterna. Ok, a lanterna é para iluminar, mas porque existe a opção de ligá-la e desligá-la? Não muda em absolutamente nada os confrontos com os poltegeists (eles te acham de qualquer jeito) e quando a desligamos perdemos visão do ambiente, já que grande parte de Sylvio é com baixa iluminação.

Por falar em poltergeists, o combate no jogo é bem bobo. Nem precisamos perder tempo comentando.

Mesmo com esse lamaçal de desgraça dá para tiramos alguns pontos positivos.

As dublagens são boas. A protagonista é tímida em suas falas, embora competente, já os áudios que coletamos de uma tal de Bobby que trabalhou no parque são bem interessantes.

A trilha sonora nos poucos momentos que se mostra presente, também me agradou. Curioso que ela ocorre na área aberta do parque. É uma trilha synthwave anos 80 e que contrasta demais com o clima do jogo em si. Sei lá, talvez seja isso que me chamou mais atenção, justamente por quebrar a monotonia que é percorrer o parque de um ponto a outro só para desbloquear o acesso para a próxima fase.

E por fim, o chamariz principal de Sylvio, [i]electronic voice phenomena[/i] (EVP), ou em bom português, fenômenos de voz eletrônica (FVE). Todo o jogo gira ao redor de tentarmos capturar mensagens ocultas em estáticas com um poderoso gravador de última geração. Sempre que matar um poltergeist você vai gravar uma mensagem dele, que vai te indicar a localização de objetos/ações para prosseguir na fase. Além do já decifrado é possível usar recursos AVANÇADÍSSIMOS do gravador para procurar mais mensagens ocultar em velocidade rápida, lenta ou para trás (não é para descobrir palavras satânicas igual se fazia com os discos da Xuxa, ok?). E é isso. Essa é a parte boa do jogo. Mentira, a história também é minimamente, interessante.

Sylvio é um jogo com uma premissa interessante e que tenta usar algo ainda pouco explorado nos games, mas sua parte técnica e jogabilidade são tão fracas que ele não vai entrar no nosso top de todos os tempos da última semana.

review: I found this game being a combination of good ideas implemented in an horrible and buggy gameplay. Let's start with the good stuff: the mic and audio recorder are a great way for building a tense and mysterious atmosphere; I also found voice acting well made, great sound design and good music too. As for the graphics, they're crude but I personally don't mind, I actually think it suits the genre. author: {'steamid': '76561198090716728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1648848881}
review:
Sylvio jest grą indie różniącą się od sporej części horrorów tym, że nie próbuje cię przestraszyć na siłę. W grze tej istnieje nieskomplikowany system walki i jego wykorzystane jest wymagane do przejścia, ale przeciwnicy mogą cię zaskoczyć tylko jeśli się zespawnują obok ciebie. Naraz może istnieć tylko jeden i stan pokonania każdego jest zapisywany, więc na szczęście nie zdarza się to często i trudno jest utknąć. Sama porażka w walce również nie daje powodów, by podskoczyć na krześle.
Gra polega na poszukiwaniu śladów bytu duchów z pomocą mikrofonu i przewijania nagrań w poszukiwaniu ukrytych wiadomości. Duchy, jak to mają w zwyczaju, nie dają jasnych odpowiedzi, ale z czasem historia nabiera wyraźniejszego kształtu. Wszystkiemu towarzyszy atmosfera tajemnicy i lekkiego napięcia w próbach zrozumienia co się wydarzyło, a same wiadomości potrafią wzbudzić w niepokój w podświadomości.
Polecam grę wszystkim, którzy znają angielski i szukają nastrojowej gry bez obawiania się o tanie sztuczki wzbudzania strachu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995985473', 'num_games_owned': 2646, 'num_reviews': 321, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 780, 'last_played': 1604770976}
review:
Mechanically, I don't think this is a good game, but conceptually, and as a statement piece, I find [i]Sylvio[/i] really brilliant. The reliance on dread atmosphere over cheap, haunted house jump scares for a player-interpretative narrative call back to a brighter time when games like [i]Silent Hill[/i] ruled the proverbial roost. I also don't know of anything else that uses EVP as its core mantra, or at the very least, not so successfully.

That said, the level design is atrocious. While each area fills you with unease, they're too sprawling and lacking in guidance to successfully navigate given the lack of a map or even a compass; expect to look up a guide if you want to actually find all the hidden messages, as well as plenty of failed experimentation over actual progress given the poor tutorial/mechanical explanation and physics-related bugs.

Ammunition is another recurring problem. There's different types of ammo for the potato gun; some are for solving puzzles, while others are used to combat aggressive spirits. Unfortunately, you can only queue up ammo as the barrel empties, not swap sets entirely. This inevitably results in wasted pesticide—your source of air pressure—spent on emptying the cannon just to swap in a metal ball to knock open a door, in turn leaving you vulnerable to spirits if you didn't a. pick up some ammo boxes along the way (which don't carry over to the next level) or b. ran back to the car to reload.

Surprisingly, the voice acting and original score are exceptionally well done, particularly for an independently developed game. Juliette—the protagonist—sounds like a moody, exhausted Björk, something that puts me at ease despite fumbling through red-misted woodlands.

More crucial, however, is that despite being kind of broken and janky and not very well thought out as a game, I still felt compelled to see [i]Sylvio[/i] through to the end, driven off of atmosphere and narrative intrigue alone, something that's a bit of a lost art in the survival horror niche today.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970338944', 'num_games_owned': 1514, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 780, 'last_played': 1601746823}
review:
Sylvio has some great ideas. Unfortunately they're wrapped in a seriously buggy product. The atmosphere and setting are intriguing, and the ghost recording elements are fascinating and really draw you into the plot. The downside is that the puzzles swing wildly between easy and extremely obtuse. Which elements of the game are interactive, and the general physics, are not particularly well explained and can lead to some frustrating moments where a puzzle solution seems slightly out of your reach for an unclear reason. This reaches its apex in the final level, which happens to be the most bland of all the levels graphically and design-wise while also managing to place items you need in positions that make little sense other than to extend your time walking around this extremely dull area.

The combat is also extremely basic, and it is never really clear what exactly will 'kill' you. Some enemies seem to damage you simply by being nearby, and as they can float through walls you will regularly find yourself dying by an enemy that you have never even seen. There is also no way to change ammunition, so if you find yourself with the wrong ammo for a situation you are forced to waste whatever you have loaded into the gun before you can put the correct one in.

The driving sections of the game are extremely basic. It is simply: A) Drive in this direction, don't hit any trees. B) Record some sounds. C) Repeat. You will regularly find yourself at the whims of the game's very basic physics, and it is a blessing that the game includes a button to right your car. Unfortunately you have to do four almost identical driving levels through the course of the game and it never gets any more interesting.

I'm surprised by the number of positive reviews for this game, which suggests that horror game fans are so starved of content that they will lap up anything without being critical of its shortcomings.

review:
The interface is too obscure for me. Sometimes your microphone shows some countdown, no idea what that means. Sometimes you get some audio fragments, not sure when and how. You get attacked by dark orbs which are sometimes invisible (or almost invisible?). If you shoot them, some stuff happens, but I'm not sure weather they're taking damage or not. And a fair warning: As a non-native speaker you'll have a hard time. Understanding words in the static his hard to impossible, and one of the narrators (Bobby) has such a faint voice (without subtitles) that it's hard to get anything he says.

developer_response:
Hey there, sorry about the experience. Just wanted to give you an answer to the things you find unclear. 

The countdown on the mic shows your distance in metres from the thing the mic is currently picking up. It can be used to find spots of interest, or orbs to shoot.

After shooting an orb, it disappears and you will record audio. The audio can then be analyzed with your recorder.

You will see what kinds of ammo you have in your pipeline. When loading it's filled from left to right, hence the next ammo going out is on the far right on the UI.

Hidden messages are found when you adjust the playback in different speeds.

You exit the recorder by pressing Q, or use 4 to toggle.

Thanks for the feedback about Bobby's voice. 

Feel free to mail me at bugs@stroboskop.com if you have any questions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035599199', 'num_games_owned': 1983, 'num_reviews': 493, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1586212690}
review:
Really good game.
It goes to the other end of the spectrum from the standard unity horror jump-scare-a-thon.  Instead it succeeds in crafting a masterful atmosphere that is an absolute joy to revel in.  It's a real slow burn, with a grimey, retro feel, right down to the minimalist synth soundtrack, which is very pleasing.
You play as an EVP-aficionado, or electronic voice phenomena junkie, who decides that the best thing to do to try out her new death-walkie-talkie is to to set off into an abandoned themepark in the middle of the night and chase up some spooks.
The game's mechanic essentially boil down to 4 things:
*Use your mic to find sources of EVP and record the audio
*Scour back and forth, forwards and reverse, at high and low speed, through this audio to eek out the snippets of dialogue imparted by the lingering dead - this definitely raises the hair on more than one occasion!
*Blast evil spirits with your nail/potato gun
*Get guided to items by the spirits and use them to progress through the, occasionally convoluted, puzzles.
And this core loop continues through a solid 7-8 hour journey.  The overall story of a huge tragedy befalling a group of people unfolds over the course of this journey.  And while some of the overall story beats are completely obtuse (and that ending, absolutely bonkers), but what is thoroughly enjoyable is the occasional engagements you have with specific named ghosts via a candlelit seance, where you find out how they died, and why they linger on.
In terms of polish this game is definitely on the rougher side, and it doesn't do a great job of explaining things to you.  I was 2/3 of the way through the game before I realised you could drive around in your car in the level, and not just use it as the 'load-next' button at the end of completing a level.
But persevere through some of that jank and you'll find an absolutely unique gem that will swallow up a couple of evenings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081477001', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1493323248}
review:
[b][i]Sylvio[/i] is by no means a conventional horror [/b]for so many reasons.

1. Conventional horror protagonists are like "Wow, we're innocent annoying milk-sucking overgrown teenager idiots! Oh no, what is this?! AAAAHHHH!!". [b]Julliette here knows precisely what she's doing,[/b] where she's going and what the consequences can be. She goes looking for supernatural trouble, just because she feels like if she doesn't do what she does, then who will?

2.Conventional horrors hate outdoors. [b]The better part of [i]Sylvio[/i] is set outdoors.[/b] And what an outdoors it is! Surreal, red mist, half-buried shacks, rusting metal all over the place. The world of [i]Sylvio[/i] is akin to [i]Stalker[/i] in a lot of ways.

3.Conventional horrors make the protagonist passive. Here [b]you're always on the active side[/b] - looking for ghosts with your mic, making your way towards them, not away from them.

4.Conventional horrors do screamers and try to play on your reflexes. Or if not - then create the sense of panic or dread, like in [i]Alien:Isolation[/i] or evoke the feeling of being lost and confused like in projects by [i]Bloober Team[/i]. Sylvio does noting of that. The feeling you get from playing it is not fear or dread so much as [b]a delicate mixture of apprehension, curiosity, gloom and awe[/b].

5.[b]Conventional horrors never get this scary.[/b] No conventional horror has this feeling when you start catching something on your mic out there. And then you suddenly see that while you are standing still, the number on your distance meter is changing. And it's slowly getting lower. Which means whatever it is you caught on your mic - it's getting closer. No conventional horror will just let you come out of the barn and behold a three-story-high black human figure against a red sky. No intense music, no screamer, just the raging static in your mic. The figure isn't aggressive, it's just standing there, do what you want about it. It's bewildering.

Sylvio is subtle, generous, mechanically original and simply beautiful despite its simplistic graphics. It's also [b]one of the best horror games you'll ever play[/b].

review:
I was gifted this game and I wasn't sure what to expect from it. I was thoroughly pleased by this game and its atmosphere. It is an atmospheric adventure game with some horror tones to it. I didn't really find it scary at all, quite the opposite. The graphics, music, pacing, and supernatural elements made me feel quite at home and was a rather relaxing experience. I loved the low fi look of this game, the grungy looking graphics really add to the atmosphere. Especially all the foggy red nonsense you see in some areas. There were a few things I was quite confused about initially because certain things weren't explained, especially if you don't get most of the collectibles. I wasn't satisfied just finishing the game, I went back gave this game a 100% completion.  I really didn't expect to do that. All in all if you like adventure games with some decent puzzles, first person perspective and some supernatural elements. You really can't go wrong. Sure there were a couple of bugs that let me sequence break a couple of puzzles on accident but eh it didn't detract from my experience.

review:
Sylvio is a unique horror game with audio being the main focus and it does it well.
Instead of running for your life or kill monsters, you explore a park decades after it's been abandoned from a disaster, with the purpose of helping ghosts.
To help, you communicate with the ghosts using evp and seances. And that's were Sylvio's audio shines, forwarding and rewinding audio to try and decode the hidden messages and be chilling at times. The low whispers, static, low noises in the distance, and the unsettling emptiness is makes with a wonderful horror game that we need in the sea of jumpscares and monster chases.
More people need to play this hidden gem of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198370704704', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1561408149}
review:
Created by a small team of Swedish developers, Sylvio takes the Horror Collectathon gameplay that Slenderman popularized and completely innovates it into one of a kind experience steeped in mystery and exploration. Despite what some have said, Silent Hill was not an intentional inspiriation, but Twin Peaks most definitely was. Overall I would recommend this game and I do not regret my time playing it. However, Sylvio is admittedly not a flawless game and there are some minor gripes I have with it. 

My biggest gripe being that, as others have criticized the game for, it can eventually feel a bit tedious at times due to back tracking. Personally, I think that this issue could have easily been rectified by adding a sprint feature and/or maybe even an in-game map. Beyond that, a minor gripe is that the main character's actress doesn't really speak/comment on her surroundings all that often and whenever she does it is in an odd soft monotone, the latter of which was apparently an intentional artistic choice on the developers' part.

Both of these gripes have thankfully addressed in the game's sequel.

"Думаю, я смогу открыть дверь с помощью какого-нибудь предмета" - подсказывает героиня, подбираю дрын, картинка показывает знак дрына посередине экрана и справа внизу вдруг вылезает... портфельчик (?!), в левой руке по-прежнему фонарь. Вопрос на засыпку: чем я держу дрын - а это на секундочку фонарный столб - может, ртом? И почему я его не вижу? И какова вероятность, что героиня вообще в состоянии подять такую тяжесть? Как этот нежданный сюрреализм перевести в образы, не связанные с приемом тяжелых психотропов? Какой тайной мудростью продиктовано неактивность кнопки ESC с заменой на Q в меню (попробуй догадаться) на фоне патологической ненависти к использовании мыши? И, разумеется, дефолтное управление приварено намертво - действительно, зачем его менять и так же хорошо. Да я даже не желаю знать что там будет дальше - безусловный манибэк.

review:
This is a truly beautiful game. An unsettling game where there is no threat of jumpscares. All you have is a recording device and a potato gun, so strap in.

I fully expected to dislike Sylvio but I'm glad I was wrong. Sylvio is a rare breed of horror, the kind that makes your heart beat faster and makes you uncomfortable but you still will want to know more.

It's not without its flaws, of course. Some puzzles can be a bit confusing, there's a rather annoying bug that I experienced were the menu closed but I wasn't given control, and it's easy to get frustrated in some parts of the game.

But the pros outweigh the cons. The music is eerie, the atmosphere is just perfect and the recordings will give you pause.

Without the use of jumpscares or frightening creatures, the creepy recordings perfectly capture the otherworldly vibe.

Also a pro, this game works well on older computers. So if you're a horror fan with an average computer, you can still play this game nicely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004798252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1519467010}
review:
Had perhaps the coin landed on its other side, I would have begrudgingly given Sylvio a positive rather than a negative review. For nearly every negative aspect the game unfortunately sports, a feeble, and occasionally justifiable, positive one can be provided in return; Sylvio gets all-so-close to giving as much as it takes. And had I been somewhat more charitable I would have tipped the other way, but in review of all I just played I can't rightly recommend what is in effect more a chore than a pleasance. 

Sylvio boasts the unique gameplay mechanic of audio-record investigation, as you'll be collecting scraps of audio to review and investigate, only to eventually further parse and evaluate. Doing this is essential to forwarding the game as it's the sole means of progression; the audio investigation is the fulcrum by which the game depends. In addition there is a paltry smattering of puzzle-solving, some flimsy and awkward gunplay, and a whole lot of nauseous exploration. It needn't be said that considering the nature of the game, graphical shortcomings can be forgiven, but the length of Sylvio (a game which boasts 10-odd hours) and its murky, crimson-fogged environments make for quite the ugly picture. Add to this a lack of diversity for just about everything (environment, enemies, items, collectibles, objectives, etc.) and you get a game that has exhausted all its positive, and in one case unique, attributes within the first few levels--and by the later levels completely ruined by its merciless repetitiveness and tediousness. 

The audio investigation, and associated creepy, ghostly voices and nocturnal seances, is an element of the game that is truly off-putting the first times it's executed. And in the game's defence I cannot think of another game that manipulates audio with this much efficaciousness: it's the core mechanic driving the game, and it functionally and emotionally works. But then you do it again. And again. And again. This action you do ad nauseam. By the third or so level the game has completely revealed what it is; the game quickly reveals just how bereft it is. By attempting to develop a long game, with an unnecessarily large environment, too much time was spent on blandly lengthening the already parchment-thin novelty present, where instead a shorter and sharper experience would have been endlessly preferable. It's understandable that featuring a longer play-time makes for an appealing Store Page bullet point, and undoubtedly appeals to many gamers, but the length of a game should always be in balance with the resources available. A confusing story and unengaging audio clips do not adequately recompense a mechanically poor game with a whopping two enemy types and a whole lot of frustrating, insipid levels.

If it seems that the previous two paragraphs aren't commensurate with the ambivalent preface, it's because I am actually disappointed that a game that so perfectly nails the horror movie creepiness of distorted audio and its manipulation, also happens to be a game that is whelmingly tedious. It's clear that developers cared about their product: evinced by the dedication to its core idea; the plethora of secrets and collectibles; and a dedication to their story (whether it's confusing and poorly communicated or not). But sometimes that's not enough. For me it wasn't. It may be for you. Make your own choice and don't feel poorly about it either way.
developer_response: I realize it's been four years, so apologies for getting back to you so late. Just wanted to say that I hear the critique. It's a tricky balance, to say enough but not too much of the story. I realize the story is well hidden in obscurity, and that might be frustrating to some. Appreciate you taking the time to write the review.

review:
This game is superb if you belong to the group of people who are looking for games that are experiences far away from the mainstream. This game certainly belongs in that group.

The core mechanic of this game is a sound recorder that picks up on voices from the other side. When you talk to these voices the recordings need to be analyzed and played forwards and backwards at different speeds. Only that way can you understand what a spirit is trying to tell you. This way you will also piece together the mystery of the pace you are exploring. It's a very unique gameplay mechanic and lends itself to a lot of interesting plot development.

It is created by basically one person alone so please keep that in mind and maaaaybe try the demo first?
Because of this a few things might throw you off. First and foremost - the graphics. This game looks like a PS2 game. And not a good one at that. Keeping in mind, though, how much content there is in the final product that is still impressive. The controls are very basic as well. The game basically uses Unity's standard FPS controller in the first iteration - which means no headbobbing, running or ducking. Or in other words: controls are not bad but feel a little like wolfenstein. From 1992. Sounds can sometimes also be a little repetetive. But look beyond that and you get a psychological horror experience that is eerie, chilling and creates atmosphere without ever falling back into cheap scares.

The best I can compare it to is finding and reading an independent comic by a local artist. Someone who self-publishes only a very small amount of his comics  and sells most of it on conventions, local comicbook stores or his own website. That small thing that would not be picked up by a large publisher which still ends up the thing that you read and fall in love with for all the right reasons despite not being printed in fukll color or on glossy paper.

The game certainly is very rough around the edges and definetely not for mainstream players BUT If you are the kind of person who can appreciate a rough gem with atmosphere over the usual jumpscares: What are you waiting for?

author: {'steamid': '76561197989290281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 315, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1508325877}
review:
https://youtu.be/guWuRGVI3nE

Sylvio is a game that tries to cover a lot of bases. However this does lead to a game that comes with some issues as a result of this. So It has point and click, fps, open world exploration and jumping puzzles. And of course the EVP mechanic in which you use a tape recorder to decode messages from the dead. The game also deos not do much in the way of hand holding either. 

However it is fair to say that other than the EVP mechanic, the other elements are somewhat rough around the egdes. And there is also some bugs and glitches thrown in as well. For example the shooting mechanic is over complicated with two tyoes of ammo, but no way to switch directly between them, as well as the pressure in your gun effecting its range and accuracy. Add to that even when you get a clear hit on your target, the game may not register the hit. 

Jumping can be floaty and impresice, and sometimes you can jump into areas that will freeze your character in place forcing you to restart. 

On the plus side, the game is a decent length, the EVP mechanic interesting and the voice acting and audio in general is good. So all in all this is really a diamond in the rough. However it will not be for everyone, and if you like a more polished experience then look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019851262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1507156157}
review:
This is a rare kind of horror game which manages to be really unsettling without resorting to any jump scares.
You walk an abandoned family park and record ghost voices, then analyse these recordings in search for any clues. You do it by playing the recording slower, faster, backwards etc. It's an interesting and unique mechanics - and certainly a very strong point of this game. The recordings might seem random and chaotic at first, but fortunately you can return to your notes later (no need to listen to them all again - good!) and a bigger, unnerving picture starts to emerge.

Sylvio is also a very crude game in places: it has some collision problems, very uneven visuals (ranging from average to very bad). To make things worse, it employs a "videogame-logic" to many puzzles, forces you to go through a few abysmal jumping-and-walking-on-ledges puzzles. 
Be prepared to persevere through these, but don't be turned off! The good things about Sylvio certainly outweigh the bad. 
The game is strangely quiet - starting from the protagonist's voice. And by "quiet" I don't mean that there's no sound! The sound part is actually great and builds most of Sylvio's atmosphere. When nobody screams, even a small whisper can make you shiver.

If you like horror games, this one's very unique and strange. I want more games that are so courageous!
And if you don't like horror games, give it a shot as well. Nothing will jump on you nor eat your brains out - and you'll get to uncover an unsettling story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988763074', 'num_games_owned': 5152, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1506258372}
review:
Interesantísima propuesta de la mano del desarrollador Sueco Niklas Swanberg. Sylvio es un juego de terror y exploración basado en el sonido. A pesar de tener unos gráficos muy normalitos la calidad y detalles de audio junto con una gran banda sonora sintetizada hace que la experiencia sea muy inmersiva.

La historia trata sobre Juliette Waters, una "sensitiva" capaz de escuchar por medio de un equipo de audio especializado los espíritus de las personas que no han podido descansar en paz (Inquietante, verdad, Iker?). La acción transcurre en un parque de atracciones abandonado, bastante grande la verdad, que se puede explorar a pie o en coche, con multitud de secretos y audios extra por descubrir. Tiene una atmosfera enrarecida, donde todo es bosque, sonidos de ambiente y niebla de color rojo sangre que hace que pienses que estas en un sueño constante. Los puzles son sencillitos pero están bien pensados.

A pesar de ciertos bugs molestos que no llegan a romper el juego pero sí que te pueden hacer perder el tiempo, Sylvio es una gran experiencia con un buen precio, con muchísimo trabajo detrás por parte de su desarrollador proporcionando un "agradable" resultado. Es muy necesario, aunque no obligatorio, tener un buen equipo de sonido (amplificado es la leche) para poder disfrutarlo al máximo. Sylvio no es un juego de sustos tipo screamers, es pura atmosfera único en su estilo.

Este Otoño verá la luz su segunda parte, donde este Developer tiene un comprador fijo.

7,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198066310618', 'num_games_owned': 3195, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1502701771}
review:
TLDR: Sylvio is a diamond in the rough. It successfully manages to separate itself from the plethora of underdeveloped indie horror games on the market. Indeed, it is lacking in the visual department, but it more than makes up for that with it's genuinely innovate gameplay mechanics. If you are looking for a light horror game or some mysterious adventure then you should really give Sylvio a go.

[h1] [b]###Full Review###[/b] [/h1]

[h1] [b]Overview[/b] [/h1]

Sylvio is a 1st person horror adevnture game. You are Juliette Waters, exploring a dilapidated family theme park, armed with a microphone and a blunderbuss that can shoot anything you pick off the ground. You can explore the large levels, picking up audio samples with your microphone and decoding them to reveal clues. This is an interesting game progression mechanic that works very well. The levels are large and open ended, and you're sometimes able to drive your car around.

[h1][b] Components[/b] [/h1]

[b]Visuals[/b] - This is an indie horror game made in Unity, so that may put some people off. Unfortunately the visuals won't do it much justice; the graphics look dated by almost a decade. On the contrary, the game manages to pull off an atmospheric and creepy aesthetic which is enough to immerse you. And since the game is so dark and sombre, the lack of graphical detail isn't a big issue. The lighting with the torch is decent, but just don't expect any dynamic shadows.

[b]Audio[/b] - The voice actor for the protagonist is a bit of a mixed bag. While the voice acting quality is alright, it definitely lacks emotion and enthusiasm. One time in the game you suddenly fall through a hole in the ground, which is quite frightful. In response, the protagonst humorously proclaims "I'm not getting back out that way," in a quiet whisper. Every line the protagonist speaks is quiet and sometimes difficult to hear, so thank goodness for subtitles. The music is definitely a positive aspect, and it's got a sort of 80's horror vibe going for it, with nice electric synth sounds. 

[b]Gameplay[/b] - This game is certainly very interesting. Each enemy you 'kill' actually helps you progess in the game. Sylvio's staple mecahnic is recording and deciphering audio using the EVP recording equipment. EVP stands for electronic voice phenomena, which are voices of spirits recorded electronically (and there's even [url=https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_voice_phenomenon]study on it in real life.[/url] Using the micropone, you can pick up bits of audio after killing the creatures, or just around the place randomly. You can then playback the audio using the EVP to reveal a message, but you will also be able to find hidden messages by playing the audio in reverse and/or at different speeds. After successfully revealing the hidden messages, certain items or locations of interest will be highlighted. This is a really interesting mechanic for a horror game and it works quite well. 

For those of you looking for a scary horror game, you may be dissapointed to hear that this game is not very scary, barely at all. The game fits better into the 'adventure' genre, as you will be exploring locations, picking up items and using them to progress. Instead of relying on cheap horror tactics, this game's eeriness and intriguing story is what will be haunting you.

[b]Story[/b] - the story is slow and unravels as you play, and you can find audio tapes that also reveal some lore. The game's story might be slow, but it definitely does not fall into cliché horror tropes. Progressing the story involves holding seances to acquire information, and the EVP equipment can also be used to reveal extra hidden messages.

[b]Functionality[/b] - The game runs on the Unity engine, which I have had quite a negative experience with. However, this game is indeed very well optimised and I didn't experience any stuttering or framerate drops.

[b]UX[/b] - Sylvio makes some unusual control binding decisions, but it's easy to adapt to and the game is fairly simple overall. Using the EVP equipment is as easy as pressing the arrow keys. However, there is an odd lack of mouse support for the menus, and the in-game help guide is quite awkward to navigate. 

[h1][b]Valuation[/b][/h1]

[b]Longevity/replayability[/b] - The game isn't really long, and can be completed in under 10 hours. But you'll probably be wanting to come back for more and finding all the secrets and recording every voice, as it's a worthwhile and fun experience.

[b]Modablity[/b] - None

[b]Support[/b] - The game has received quite a bit of updates, and has even been remastered during it's time on Steam. However, the developer hasn't responded in the forums in over a year.

[b]Is it worth the money?[/b] I would say that if you get this discounted for under $10, then it's a very worthwhile experience for any fans of adventure or horror.

[h1][b] Positive Attributes [/b] [/h1]
[list]
[*] Very interesting and innovative gameplay mechanic
[*] Large open levels; hidden secrets to find
[*] The music is quite good
[*] Very well optimized
[/list]
[h1][b] Negative Attributes [/b] [/h1]
[list]
[*] Graphics are subpar
[*] Voice acting is generally OK but definitely not Sylvio's strong point
[*] The UX isn't very user friendly or convenient
[/list]

[h1] [b]Conclusion[/b] [/h1]

Sylvio is a very unique horror game and I'd definitely recommend it if your even the slightest fan of horror or mystery. It's likely unlike anything you'd ever played before.
I give this game a 7/10 - an innovative indie horror game with lack of polish

review:
This is a fantastic game. Not very advanced in gameplay or graphics, but the story makes up for all this. There is even a few bugs still... It is a rather easy game, with a few easy puzzles. Sometimes there is a bit to much guessing of what to do or how do it. Not that it is difficult, you just have to walk around and find the next thing to do.

I won't tell about the story (apart of chasing ghosts), but this is a great way of telling the story. Many games are about doing stuff, because that itself is fun/great/what ever, but playing this game itself is not much (yet still very eerie and scary), but the story you unfold during the game is what this is all about. The story would not have been great in a book, but this way of unrevelling is great.

Get all the reels in the game, and listen to them after the game (in order), and everything makes completly sense... in a scary way.

The game takes only about 8 hours to complete (depending on how much you run around randomly ;) ).

review:
After watching my favorite youtuber play through this game, I knew I needed to play it myself. 

Creepy and atmospheric, Sylvio provides a unique form of game play- the ability to record and subsequently analyze EVPs, or electronic voice phenomena. Although that would be something I'd be too frightened to do in real life, doing so in the game is a chilling yet thrilling experience. 

The puzzles in this game are nothing to scoff at either; some are particularly easy, while others appear easy yet provide a challenge, a need to think outside the box and adjust your expectations. 

Having a gun for fighting the shadowy blobs and figures (and solving those tricky puzzles) provides just enough action to keep your heart racing and balance out the quiet item hunt and freaky voices begging for your attention.

Speaking of, the sound design is eerie- even though I know it's only a game, all designed and recorded by other people, a shiver still traces my spine at the sound of garbled voices coming from seemingly thin air.

There seems to be no end to the secrets as well- I find myself revisiting previous areas to seek out all the voices in the static and discover the secret codes and items.

I highly recommend this game if you enjoy atmospheric horror and adventure/exploration games.

review:
Sylvio is a criminally overlooked game, in my opinion.
I first found out about it through a stream by one of the Vinesauce members, and I remember being so wholly fascinated by the concept. When I finally got to play it myself, I had much fun exploring the unsettling landscape and learning all of the lore it had to offer.

I will admit, that while the game doesn't seem terribly spooky at times while you're wandering around, turning around to suddenly find that a hostile black mist is phasing through the wall in your direction can be absolutely heart attack-inducing. I actually screamed in my husband's ear once when it happened xD.
The recordings of the ghosts are fairly unsettling, as well, especially if you're easily creeped out by the uncanny valley-esque weirdness of warped voices telling you about how they died.

I'm definitely looking forward to playing the sequel!

author: {'steamid': '76561197960514574', 'num_games_owned': 1956, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1504221778}
review:
Sylvio est un jeu d'horreur indépendant réalisé par une toute petite équipe de suédois. On y incarne Juliette Waters, une jeune femme qui va chercher à communiquer avec les fantômes dans un ancien parc d'attractions. Celui-ci est abandonné suite à un glissement de terrain. Elle va donc s'aventurer seule à pied ou en voiture dans un environnement hostile dans lequel elle va chercher à enregistrer la voix des morts et à l'interpréter grâce à son système d'enregistrement analogue. Emmbarquez dans une aventure originale et comme vous n'en avez encore jamais vécu!

Sylvio n'est pas un jeu dans lequel on risque de sursauter ou de se faire massacrer par des esprits vengeurs et autres fantomes démoniaques. On va découvrir une histoire macabre de famille en parcourant le parc et ses différentes attractions et autres endroits emblématiques. Il va falloir découvrir les tenants et aboutissants de ce parc un peu à l'aveugle. Le moins que l'on puisse dire c'est que le jeu n'est pas très explicite sur ses mécaniques et sur le cheminement logique de ses énigmes. En effet, le gameplay se divise en plusieurs parties entrecoupées de trajets jusqu'à la prochaine zone à explorer. On commence par chercher des indices et autres objets permettant d'avancer. Ensuite, il va falloir aller à la chasse aux fantomes grâce à un fusil artisanal. Une fois vaincu, on aura la possibilité de communiquer avec lui et ensuite d'analyser l'enregistrement à plusieurs vitesses.


Who you gonna call?

Ces manipulations sont un passage obligé afin d'avancer dans la résolution des énigmes. Une fois que l'on a extrait toutes les informations de l'enregistrement, on peut passer au suivant. Au passage, on utilise un micro afin d'enregistrer la voix des morts, il ne s'agira pas seulement d'enregistrer la seule voix du fantôme lors de ses apparitions mais aussi un peu partout dans les niveaux ce qui impliquera pas mal d'exploration dans les niveaux et de chasse aux achievements. On pourra également faire la chasse à des partitions de musique et autres enregistrements reliés à des corbeaux afin de découvrir une histoire parallèle. La progression est linéaire dans l'histoire du jeu mais elle ne l'est pas forcément au sein des niveaux, le jeu nous affichera des indices mais on ne pourra pas forcément les utiliser tant que l'on aura pas trouvé ce qu'il faut faire avant. C'est d'ailleurs un des rares problèmes du jeu, il est parfois assez confus et on peut passer une heure à chercher ce que l'on peut faire avec les objets que l'on vient de trouver, les combinaisons ne sont pas forcément logiques et il faudra s'armer de patience pour comprendre la logique derrière certaines énigmes.

Au niveau technique, le jeu est assez moyen avec une utilisation assez modérée du moteur Unity même dans la version remasterisée du jeu qui est sortie cette année et sur laquelle je base mon test. Les graphismes sont plats et les textures vont du moche au passable. La musique est plutôt bonne mais elle est très discrète et n'intervient quasiment que lors des phases en voiture. La maniabilité est correcte que ce soit avec la manette ou avec le combo clavier-souris. On peut sauter, utiliser des objets sur des éléments du décor ou activer des mécanismes. Les phases de combat sont assez particulière avec une gestion du bon type de munition à utiliser et de la pression du pistolet. Certaines interactions avec le décor sont logique tandis que d'autres sont plus nébuleuses voir chanceuses.


Not Alone in the Dark.

Sylvio n'est pas un jeu de combat ni même un jeu qui cherche les scarejumps. On évite également le côté Slender grâce au système de combat contre les esprits des fantômes mais aussi contre leur représentation physique sous la forme d'un géant faisant office de boss de niveau. On passe plus de temps à tenter de capter les voix des esprits et à analyser ce qui leur est arrivé. Il n'y a rien de perturbant au niveau visuel, pas de cadavres, pas de poupées qui font peur, pas d'animatroniques, rien de tout ceci. Sylvio est une expérience à part, pour peu que l'on occulte un tant soit peu les gros défauts du jeu, on passe 10-12 heures de véritable bonheur vidéoludique. Découvrir les secrets que renferme le jeu devient vite un plaisir plutôt qu'une corvée. Découvrir ce qui est arrivé à tout ce petit monde et refaire plusieurs fois le jeu pour y dénicher des enregistrements cachés devient presque une obsession.


Ne vous attendez pas à un jeu AAA ou à un jeu qui vous tient la main, on est loin de tout ca. Il m'est souvent arrivé de passer 30-40 minutes à chercher partout dans un niveau sans comprendre ou trouver de suite logique à mes actions précédentes. La réalisation est sommaire, on est obligé de passer son clavier en anglais pour pouvoir contrôler son personnage au clavier et il arrive souvent que l'on se retrouve bloqué dans le décor ou à court de munitions pour déclencher une ouverture de porte par exemple. Le jeu permet de sauvegarder à chaque action principale mais on recommancera toujours près de sa voiture. Les indices secondaires prrésentés par des distances et des ??? ne sont pas toujours clairs et ils induisent en erreur lors de notre progression dans le jeu. La voix de l'actrice est excellente mais on ne l'entend pas très bien ce qui également fort dommage!

They keep following me!

Sylvio n'est pas un jeu parfait mais il a une âme, un vrai sens de l'histoire et l'utilisation du magnétophone apporte un réel plus! On se croirait dans un film d'horreur des années 80, l'hémoglobine et les ectoplasmes en moins! Non exempt de bugs gênants, le jeu reste jouable du début à la fin sans réelle perte d'intérêt graduelle qui plombe la plupart des jeux du genre. Le final est brillant même si on a besoin de quelques temps pour bien comprendre ce qu'il s'est réellement passé. En fonction de ce que vous avez trouvé dans les niveaux, vous découvrirez des éléments en plus à la fin. Si les versions PS4 et Xbox One utilisent la même version que celle à laquelle j'ai joué, vous ne devriez pas être déçus!
